page.title: 09CHURCH OF ST.PETER
page.content: St. Peter's stands in the centre of the town near the Square. There was a building on the site soon after the time of the Domesday Book, but it was altered and extended in later times. The North and South doors of the church were built in Norman times and have the rounded arches which the Normans were good at building. Since the starting of the Parish Communion Service in the 1960s this has become the most popular act of worship. The Alternative Services Book 1980 is used mostly, but the Book of Common Prayer has not been abandoned. There are services in the church most days of the week. Relationships with other Christian denominations in the town are good, and United Services are held several times a year. The Good Friday Act of Witness in the Square is one of the most important.
